question: During an IFR arrival in VMC, who is responsible for traffic avoidance?

choices.choice: The radar controller
The pilot in command
The approach controller

subject: Regulations
explanation:
ICAO Annex 2:

  • ICAO Annex 2 outlines rules for the safe operation of aircraft.
  • Paragraph 2.1.3 states that pilots are responsible for the safe and efficient operation of their aircraft.
  • In VMC conditions, this includes maintaining visual separation from other aircraft.
  • Paragraph 2.3 emphasizes that pilots retain the responsibility for collision avoidance.
  • While Air Traffic Control (ATC) provides advisories, they do not assume responsibility for traffic avoidance.
  • The pilot in command must make decisions based on traffic visibility.
  • Safety remains the ultimate responsibility of the pilot, especially in visual conditions.

question: What is the purpose of a “Time Approach Procedure”?

choices.choice: To maintain a specified speed during the approach procedure
To pass the specified point inbound at the previously notified time
To apply a step down descent between aircraft in the approach sequence

subject: Regulations
explanation:
In Timed Approach,

Aircraft are to be give a time at which to pass the specified point inbound (the purpose
of which is to achieve the desired interval between successive landings on the runway
while respecting the applicable separation minima at all times including runway occupancy
period). The time determined is to be passed to the pilot to allow sufficient time for him/
her to arrange the flight to comply.

question: Under what conditions can ATC clear an aircraft for a “visual approach”?

choices.choice: The meteorological visibility must not be less than 8km
The approach must be passing the FAF
The air traffic controller will provide separation to other controlled traffic

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Separation Responsibility: Air Traffic Control (ATC) is responsible for providing separation between aircraft making a visual approach and all other arriving or departing traffic.
  • Transfer of Control: For arriving IFR traffic in Instrument Meteorological Conditions (IMC), the Approach Controller will transfer control of the aircraft to the Aerodrome Controller at a designated point during the approach.

question: For controlled traffic near an airport, when may separation minima be reduced?

choices.choice: At the discretion of the air traffic controller
When the commander in the following aircraft has the preceding aircraft in sight and is able to maintain own separation
If the commander of the involved aircraft so requests

subject: Regulations
explanation:
In the vicinity of aerodromes, the separation minima may be reduced if:

a) adequate separation can be provided by the aerodrome controller when each aircraft is continuously visible to this controller; or

b) each aircraft is continuously visible to flight crews of the other aircraft concerned and the pilots thereof report that they can maintain their own separation; or

c) in the case of one aircraft following another. The flight crew of the succeeding aircraft reports that the other aircraft is in sight and separation can be maintained.

question: Under what circumstances can a “visual approach” be performed?

choices.choice: During VFR flight, there should be a visibility of 5 km or more
During IFR flight, if the cloudbase is 1000ft more than the appropriate DA or MDA for that procedure
During IFR flight. if there is permanent sight on the movement area and the underlying ground

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Arriving IFR aircraft may be cleared for a Visual Approach if:

  1. The pilot can maintain visual reference to terrain.
  2. The reported ceiling is at or above the approved initial approach level.
  3. The pilot reports meteorological conditions allow a visual approach and landing during an instrument approach.

question: What is the minimum divergence required between departure tracks to allow one-minute separation?

choices.choice: 30° immediately after take-off
15° immediately after take-off
45° immediately after take-off

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Wake turbulence separation procedures for aircraft departures.

  • Purpose of Sequencing: Wake turbulence separation is applied to minimize delays and maximize runway utilization.
  • Standard Separation: For IFR traffic, the standard separation between departures is 5 minutes, allowing for 12 movements per hour.
  • Reduced Separation (Same Track): This may be reduced to 2 minutes between aircraft following the same departure track, provided that the preceding aircraft has filed a flight plan speed 40 knots greater than the succeeding aircraft.
  • Further Reduced Separation (Diverging Tracks): The separation can be further reduced to 1 minute (allowing for 60 movements per hour) if the track of the succeeding aircraft diverges from that of the preceding aircraft by 45° or more.

question: What change in tailwind component must ATC report to aircraft on final approach?

choices.choice: 3kt
4kt
2kt

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Commencing final approach. At the commencement of final approach, the following
information shall be transmitted to the aircraft:
• Significant changes in the mean surface wind direction and speed;

◦ Mean head-wind component 10 kt
◦ Mean tail-wind component 2 kt
◦ Mean crosswind component 5 kt

• The latest information, if any, on wind shear and/or turbulence in the final approach
area;
• The current visibility representative of the direction of approach and landing

question: When must the EAT be given to a pilot if a delay is expected?

choices.choice: 5 minutes or more
15 minutes or more
20 minutes

subject: Regulations
explanation:
A revised expected approach time shall be transmitted to the aircraft without delay
\nwhenever it differs from that previously transmitted by 5 minutes or more or such lessor period of time as has been established by the appropriate ATS authority or agreed between the ATS units concerned.

question: If one aircraft is on straight-in approach, may another depart in any direction?

choices.choice: Until five minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway
Until ten minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway
Until two minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Straight-in Approach. If an aircraft is making a straight-in approach, a departing aircraft may take off in any direction until 5 minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the instrument runway OR in a direction which is different by at least 45 degrees from the reciprocal of the direction of approach of the arriving aircraft until 3 minutes before the arriving aircraft is estimated to be over the beginning of the instrument runway OR before the arriving aircraft crosses a designated fix on the approach track as determined by the ATS authority.

\n
